name: NARUTO SHIPPUDEN: Ultimate Ninja STORM 3 Full Burst HD
description: Live the 4th Great Ninja War and its overpowering boss fights or defy your friends in ultra dynamic online and offline ninja confrontations!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows (64bit) 7 or higher up to date Processor: Intel Core2 Duo, 3.0GHz - AMD Athlon 64 X2 Dual Core 6400+ 3.2GHz Memory: 2 GB RAM Graphics: 1024 MB video card DirectX: Version 11 Storage: 23 GB available space Sound Card: DirectX sound device

reviews.review_text: Sakura is actually useful in this game

Time for a long essay about this game because that's just how awesome this is.  NARUTO SHIPPUDEN: Ultimate Ninja STORM 3 Full Burst is a game based on the manga/anime franchise Naruto (obviously). Since this is the 3rd game, it starts the story in the middle so if you haven't played the other games (I haven't) but you have read/watched the entire series, it's all good. This game just goes on the story from the part right before the Great Ninja War. If you are a Naruto fan, this is a guaranteed 'You'll like this' game for you.  The game is a 3D style fighting game and you go can either go through the story to fight the battles that happened in the manga in the game. The one thing I like about this is that everytime a battle starts, it starts on the normal difficultly, but if you are having trouble with that battle and lost over three times, the difficultly gets lowered. I really liked that, caused me not to get stuck on certain battles.  The cutscenes are animated 3D models, and that is pretty amazing how they made them look beautiful with models, at the same level as RWBY, which is probably the best 3D animation(anime?) ever. The characters and voices were great (I think they used the same ones from the anime) and matched the story of Naruto overall.  There is one section of the game where you can play as Naruto's pregant mom and that part really cracked me up. Another thing is that everytime you buy ramen from the ramen guy in town, all your health and chakra gets restored. THE RAMEN IS MAGIC!!!!  This game is supposed to be on XBOX controllers but the PC version is also great, but has some problems. There are glitches in the game. Sometimes theres one battle that just causes the game to crash, or one specific move that will cause the game to crash. This is one of the reasons why I never actually completed the entire story within the game. One of the last battles during the Great Ninja War would keep crashing, so I gave up. (I already know what happens anyway)  I suppose one of the things I didn't like was the spread of save points. Some save points would be placed 2 minutes of each other while others are 2 hours from each other. That was one of the cons of this game since I can't play games in a marathon and I don't think I am the only one.  Overall, this game has its ups and downs but is a great game. It's also pretty long and hopefully you will enjoy it as much as I do. Thanks for reading this long essay. ^-^

I love this game to death its amazing if you love naruto or want your general beatem up. Its nice not impossible to get good at and its fun creating your own combos. Massive chaacter roster and story is nice. I like it a lot i reccomend this game

I'd be lying if I said I'd seen more than one episode of Naruto, and I'd be lying again if I said that I thoroughly enjoyed what I have seen of it. That being said, I recommend this game, albiet only circumstantially. I'll elaborate on what I mean by that.  Whether or not one considers his or herself an 'anime fan', there is surely a plentiful amount of people that find satisfaction in over-the-top ninja battles and explosive action in general. I, personally, enjoy this game because you are put right in the middle of the ridiculous madness that is a Naruto battle, and it feels very fun. I know practically nothing about the series, and by purchasing this game, I didn't hope to expand my knowledge on it. I only play the story mode (which isn't anything special except for the boss battles) to gain access to all the characters to use in multiplayer battles. There isn't much depth to that, and that is significant in  my  personal enjoyment, because if we want to get metaphorical, I didn't buy it as a game. Rather, an explosive Japanese cartoon ninja action simulator. And at being that, it excels.  If you want story, don't buy it. If you don't have friends to play with, don't buy it.  If you don't have a controller, don't buy it.   If you like fighting games on a large 3D plane, throwing fireballs at your friends or co-workers, or have ever dressed up like a ninja and run around your house yelling 'rasengan!', this one's for you.

All around great game and the bonus chapters make for good extras. My only flaw is that the controls are somewhat difficult for PC players that don't own a control pad, and aren't necessarily used to keyboard mashing.  Regardless, I definitely recommend this game to all Naruto fans - and even those who aren't fans.
Get it. The end.

Newcomers who persevere and keep on bashing away until they master the fundamentals will be rewarded greatly, but in all honesty, you might be best off tracking down at least the first NUNS game on PS3 and Xbox 360. For existing fans of the series, these are the ninjas you’re looking for. Network quirks aside, if you’ve got a PC capable of making NUNS3 sing, you won’t be disappointed.

I have been thinking about buying this game. But, I never really thought much out of a fighter game, even naruto-based game like this would be PC worthy. Well, I was wrong. It has sparked the Naruto fan inside me, even thought I was a big fan of it before. I loved this show then and kinda fell off after a while because they had a new artist change the entire look of naruto. But, I felt I should put it aside and play the game. The storyline is breathtaking, that might be a level of nerd that people aren't necessarily suppose to expose. But, it truly is one of the best storylines put into a game if you haven't watched the series. Please, if you want a single player game this is the way to go.   ALSO, KEY INFORMATION: If you don't have a controller, then this game will be dramatically less fun if you play it. Put the time and effort into getting a controller. It's super simple and costs less than the game itself. Especially since Xbox and Playstation are moving to the new console controllers. Go to google shops and or just best buy and they can sell you one, honestly cheaper than the game.   Lastly, I highly recommend this game to all my friends and gaming peers. It's well worth the time and money. However, the multiplayer I can not recommend because I don't play multiplayer on this game.
Some say that cutscenes never end...

Keyboard = BS? As my Dualshock 2 wasn't compatible with this game, keyboard was the only option I had and !'#¤% me was it hard to configure. Well the configuration per say was easy enough, but to actually bind all of the buttons needed for this game through a keyboard was a challenge in and upon itself. I believe the setup took apx 90min with some trial and error to get a grasp of the game mechanics and what worked or not.  That being said... It is most definetely playable through a keyboard given the correct settings! Don't get me wrong, a controller is a much better choice mind you... Still, you can enjoy the experience and get used to playing through the keyboard as well! Game itself? I honestly didn't feel much for it at firsthand, battles feels like a mixture between the Gekkitou Ninja Taisen series on GC and Ultimate Ninja on PS2. Overall it works but I don't enjoy them nearly as much! The overworld imo doesn't fill any meaning other than being an annoying slowdown between the progress of the game per say. Speaking of which - The game feels more like a movie! Now I've played the DBZ Budokai series and they too had fights followed by cutscenes along with various unlockables, however the game definetely was more challenging and fun due to customization of capsule skills, true you can customize your items for this particular game but at the same time I never found myself using them EVEN ONCE! Overall it is almost exactly like watching the anime with the exception of worse graphics and certain altered scenes, again for the worse.. I really !'#¤% hated it in the beginning, but as time went on and what it really comes down to is that it's still very much Naruto at it's core and naturally you DO have an interest in the characters and the story... As for the gameplay, it is extremely unbalanced! it goes from certain battles being a joke to some being insane, granted you can still S rank them within 5 tries or so. There are however during certain battles and these are mainly during the bosses when you have special objectives to be filled if you wanna achieve the highest rank. Some of these being purely !'#¤%&/ LUCK BASED!!! For me this game goes to shiets at when you're supossed to rely on luck rather than skill..  Bottom line is that you will most likely enjoy the game if you are a fan! But truth be told, there are better installments of the franchise and it's by far not a masterpiece by itself either. I think metacritic was very generous giving this game 80 or what they did.. I wouldn't give it more than 65 at the most! My advice is to pick it up on a sale at 9,99 AND NOT HIGHER, if you are to pick it up at some point. All I can say is don't expect greatness from it other than feeling a bit of nostalgia from the series, as the manga is to end within 8 weeks from typing this, it's fun in a sense to remember the past 15 years that has been Naruto. At the same time though, I can't wait till the anime is complete in order to re-watch the series and TRUELY feel nostalgic the correct way

**If you are a Naruto fan** who always wanted a good Naruto game on pc go for it, its totally worth it :D Story mode is really done nicely tho ending is sort of an alternative ending which is not canon, can't blame them for that since the time this was finished cannon story was still going without any sorts of ending. Some cut scenes are very long but animated and voiced superbly so its not a torture to watch 'em. Also in story mode its not just fight after a fight after the cut scene, instead you can explore,so some side missions,send letters(sms equivalent I guess lolz) to your friends & lot more. Even after finishing the main story mode there are so much to do if you are a perfectionist. Fighting mechanism is not complicated at all but its done really well considering this is an anime based game. To finish the story mode you don't need a controller, but its not easy with the keyboard until you get used to it. This edition have all the costume(apart from Goku costume for Naruto & hello kitty costume for Sakura,Goku costume is already ported by the community) & one story dlc included,complete edition.  About the multiplayer mode, this is where things went to hell,at least at the release. At the release netcode was so bad that was impossible to finish a single match without game getting disconnected. But I guess CC2 patched most stuff out & it is more than playable now. But you will need a good connection with good ping to get everything working pretty well. Also beware in matches there will be guys who will spam long range technique characters like no tomorrow to increase their win rank, believe me I played this when it was first out on ps3 thanks to my cousin and it was much worst, most characters CC2 patched out to reduce the unfair advantages I guess so that's a plus.   As a pc port its not a superb port but for me its an okay port considering this was CC2 first PC release. This is more like a direct emulation on pc type of port. It don't have any advanced graphics settings(you can only set resolution,supersampling & vsync) to play with. Game will need at least a good pc to run it on 1080p I guess since game is not greatly optimized to the pc platform. Also there is a 30fps cap that is hard coded to the game engine but it is not that noticeable but might change your decision. Game keys use the xbox style X,Y,A,B method and before starting the game you can map the controls of the keyboard, inside the game it shows X,Y,A,B keys.   As final thoughts this is the best Naruto game out there right now and a year ago nobody even thought there will be a pc port and the best thing is next Naruto game will be released to ps3,xbox 360 & pc simultaneously. Its not a perfect port but its a very enjoyable game, I have 100+ hours on this & this is the only game I've ever pre-ordered. Also this title is not going on sale very much so if you want it now go for it dattebayo :D  Hope my two cents helped someone with their decision =)

UNS3 is a strong fighter in it's own right, but also a good pick for people like me who more often than not, just don't enjoy fighters. This game has a very Beat-em' up feel to it.. it's also very simple by nature, with simple controls, combos and easy to perform moves. With that said, it has enough depth in the way that you can use those simple moves and turn it into a truly exciting game, full of satisfaction and devious trickery.  This game shines most in it's multiplayer. The best way to experience this game would be locally, with a mate or seven. Failing that, you can of course take to the online mode. The netcode looks like it needs work but disconnects are a thing of the past- the real beast to worry about is latency. Fighting any friend further than my own state (Western Australia) resulted in anywhere between a few milliseconds to half a second of latency, with those in my state being as responsive as a local match. Unfortunately, and this is likely due to poor Australian internet but it's still worth noting, playing any friend overseas was unplayably laggy, resulting in only frustration for both players. It kind of draws from the game, but it's more of an issue for us here.  When you do get connected, it is undoubtedly the most fun part of the game.  That is of course not to say the single player doesn't excel too, oh it does. One of the best stories in a fighting game in thanks to the rich and interesting world provided by the Naruto franchise. The story itself takes place in the same arc the currently-airing anime does at time of release, the Fourth Great Ninja War. The story is solid, it has many moments that will blow your mind and a lot of them are fully playable. Each fight is as memorable as the last, nothing feels too forced or unnecessary and the pace is set nicely too, with the exception of an almost hour-long scene that just sucks the life out of the middle of the game for a while. If I were to pick some nits I'd say that the characters are a bit too stiff and they don't move during dialogue unless it's a big scripted cutscene, but when things get good, they get fantastic. Even flashbacks are implemented into story fights as you play, giving you some GREAT perspective. Some of the story is very simpified, and it focuses more on the Main characters than the Anime does, leaving out some very interesting and emotionally impacful backstory.. but it does the job. It teaches you how to play, offers hours of entertainment and will make you excited for the franchise all over again. Sadly, the ending is a little different to what happens in canon Naruto, likely to avoid spoiler territory for the anime, and thus is a little unsatisfying. It'd be nice to have gotten that little surprise at the end- for that, I highly urge you to watch the anime, the person behind that mask.. ooh! Amazing.  For a Console port, it has it's issues. There's a lack of tweakable options.. you're given a choice of resolution and Anti-Aliasing and that's about it. With that said.... the game runs very smoothly, even at it's locked 30 Frames Per Second, and the Anti-Aliasing does it's job well, there's a very noticable difference and the quality is greatly improved over it's console counterparts, especially in just how smooth and clear the lines are, it helps solidify the feeling this is an Anime. It doesn't really 'Feel' like a port, if that makes sense- while you're playing it, it looks great, sounds great and controls great while running smoother than butter on any decent machine.  With all that said, I'd definitely recommend you give it a shot. It's got plenty of hours in store for you and is certainly a blast with friends. It's the definitive version of the game and I'm very happy it came to PC.  I'll give you guys a hint for when you start playing.. don't rely on your subs too much. It's easy to think spamming them will win you a fight but if you learn to play while conserving them and recharging often, you will dominate your friends. The Chakra dash is your best friend!

I say it's well worth it, the story mode is linear, the English VO work is a little weak, but over all the fighting mechnics in the game are fun in their own right. It's nothing new from the previous Ninja Storm games, but if this is your first foray the camera might need a little getting used to. But once you do it's very fun. Also the ninjitsu's and ultimate-jitsu's are extremely entertaining to watch. And honestly there are very little button combos to remember if any really at all. Simple and flashy.

The Short: Awesome fighting game (even if you aren't a Naruto junkie!), but make sure you have a controller and the patience to sit through the annoying matchmaking  The Long: I can't compare this game to earlier entries in the Ninja Storm series because I haven't played any; I picked this game up while it was on sale a while ago because I liked similar style fighting games (DBZ Budokai Tenkaichi) and was very pleasantly surprised.  Unlike the aforementioned Tenkaichi, all of the characters feel like they have a different playstyle and most of them have at least one unique trait that makes them viable. At first the game seems like it is all button mashing because there are no arcade-style button combos to put in, but it is not! Timing and managing your substitutions is critical otherwise you will be crushed by a more skilled player.  The storymode is great in this game. All of the critical scenes in Shippuden are re-enacted for the most part, and the cinematic battles are great.  Most people probably care about Online Mode the most though, so I'll put a good bit of my thoughts in here too:  The fun you will have Online depends on who you play with. The netcode can be spotty with this game, as I've had it drop inputs playing with someone who lives in the same town. The community can also be very frustrating, as you will see a lot of TenTen/Temari/Deidara spammers who are looking for stat-padding and spend the whole match throwing projectiles, or people who turn off assists to do infinite combos with Neji/Rock Lee.  Eventually you will find people who aren't trying to cheese out the game though, and when you do, you will have lots of fun. I recommend building a list of friends who play this game and doing tournaments, as this game can be insanely fun when your opponent isn't spamming jutsus or using cookie-cutter teams.  I haven't tried to play this game on the keyboard, I imagine it is dreadful, so make sure you bring your wired 360 controller before you buy. Cheers.
NARUTO SHIPPUDEN is the game for ninjas

Alright. Let me start off by saying that this was my first 'Ultimate Ninja Storm' game that I've completed. So if you've never played one of these, I can help you out. First off, this is a 3D fighting game that is based off of the anime 'Naruto'. This game in particular takes place during the 'Fourth Great Ninja War'. If you have never seen the show or have never read the manga of Naruto, it's going to be a bit confusing for you. I would recommend watching the show or at least doing a bit of research on Naruto if you want to understand this story. Anyways, you can move Naruto around the game map and talk to other characters to progress the story. Although, this is honestly kind of a little pointless. There's barely anything on the map aside from a few collectibles every now and then, and you can buy pretty much every thing you find in the in game shops. And sometimes, it takes quite awhile to get from one area to another. While I thought the world was pretty cool at first, it got pretty tedious running back and forth. If you were expecting a big open world game to explore in the Naruto universe, prepare to be disappointed. Anyways, the story is mostly made up of cutscenes which can be preeeeety lengthy at times. There's this one chapter where there's a cutscene that's like 50 minutes long. So if you plan to see the story, you'd better be prepared to sit back and watch. The story also has boss battles ranging from fighting regular characters to fighting massive monsters. The fights are great and in the middle of some of them, a mini cutscene activates where your character moves on their own and you have to do quick-time events for them to do a pretty cool, flashy move. These are only in the story though, not in the normal game. So if you enjoy looking at em, you'll have to replay that story mission. If you don't like QTE's, well then you don't have to worry too much as they're not in every battle and you don't need to do them much anyways. And the graphics of this game look very nice. The PC version compliments the art style nicely and everything looks so soft and smooth. It is a console port though so don't expect super high textures and jaw dropping visuals or anything. It's locked to 30 fps btw. That's kind of disappointing but the way the game plays with its smooth animations kind of makes up for it. It's still playable if you ask me. Also, something really weird which hasn't gotten fixed from past UNS games is the lip syncing of characters. Their mouths don't match with what the characters say at all and they still move even after the voice of the character has stopped which is just embarrasing. Just letting you know if you notice this happening, there's nothing wrong with your game. Moving on to the gameplay, the characters all have their standard combo attacks and can use special attacks which consume 'chakra'. This chakra can also be used to do a super move which uses up all your chakra and looks pretty cool! When you're fighting in the story against AI, their difficulty raises depending on the story conditions. For the most part, they are pretty easy. But those bosses that I mentioned earlier can also be pretty cheap at times. For example, some parts of the story make you fight multiple enemies at once and they are so annoying trying to hit you all at the same time. For them, sometimes you can't just fight normally and try to do combos. And you might end up having to just spam some moves to get them heck away from you while you focus on one of em. But like I said, most of the fights are pretty fair and there aren't too many bosses like that until you get towards the end of the game. Another thing to mention is that there's a ton of characters in this Naruto game. All the regulars like Naruto, Sasuke, Sakura, Tsunade, Kakashi, etc. And a lot of characters from Shippuden like Raikage, Mizukage, Kazekage Gaara, etc. Also, this version is Full Burst which contains all of the DLC from the regular version and the most notable addition being the extra DLC chapter which focuses on a fight with the two Uchiha brothers vs a powerful villian who I won't spoil. However, I suggest you only do this fight if you're really brave or want to complete everything the game has to offer. As this fight is far more difficult than anything in the regular game and he is by far the cheapest piece of garbage in the entire game. (I eventually beat it, but I cannot tell you how many times I died) Overall, I say it's a decent fighting game. It's worth a try but it is far from perfect.  PROS -Excellent graphics -Follows Naruto story -Tons of characters -Decent fighting system -Great animations  CONS -Bad character lip sync -Barren game world -Locked to 30 fps -Some cheap boss battles -Long cutscenes  If you're a Naruto fan, I recommend checking this one out. If you're not and just want a fighting game, feel free to get this on sale. But there's definitely better fighters out there.  7/10

You will need:  1 lb short-grain rice  8 servings of umeboshi (dried plum)  8 servings of nori (dried seaweed)   Directions:  Cook the rice.  Keep it warm, but let it cool enough so that it won't burn your hands.  Cut each nori sheet into 9 strips.  Wet your hands and sprinkle them with salt to prevent the rice from sticking to them.  Mold a handful of rice into a triangular shape with an indentation in the middle.  Press a piece of umeboshi into the indentation you left.  Wrap the rice and umeboshi in Nori strips.  Serve immediately or save for later.

So after playing this game and completing it I have made a few conclusions: If you're a Naruto Shippuden fan and follow the series, there is no point to having this game, unless you follow the games also.  if you are new to Naruto Shippuden this is a good series to start to get an idea of what has happened in the anime and manga series, (but if you are unfamiliar to the the original I would suggest looking that up before starting this series) although it doesn't have as much of the content that the anime and manga series contain.  The main purpose of this game is for you to know what is hapening in the series not for an original storyline or amazing gameplay, it's to tell you the story of Naruto Shippuden so expect a hell of a lot of cutscenes, enought that I admit drove me to the point where I stopped playing this for about a month from the bordome of sitting through all of them.  So onto what it does right and wrong, first I'll start with the pros: -It tells the story really well and does the franchise justice.  -This is one of the very few games that actually make QTE matter as you get rated on how quickly you complete the QTE with stars leading up to a maximum, if you get enough stars you wil get a secret factor which is a couple of shots from the anime and has a little bit of dialogue which is the same in the games 1 and 2 also,  -The music for the boss fights are amazing and the boss fights themselves are handled really well with the rating systems coming in to make it so much better.  -The scenes that want to make to envoke an emotion are outstanding.  -There are changes to the battle system occasionally, where instead of fighting one on one in a circle type arena, you play more like a hack n slash game where you run through different corridors and defeat a number of enemies, it's done alright but it can get annoying after a while.  So now onto the cons: -There are so many cutscenes, this game seems more like storybook than an actual game, they are also extremely long, wih most being around a good 2 or 3 minutes of just dialogue and nothing exciting happening in them, you'll find yourself skipping them towards the end just cause there was so many, like I did.  -The main battle system is nothing special, it's ripped from the second game this time adding a few more characters that feel different which is good, but it's just kind of bland with each character having a melee combo and one or two jutsu moves depending on how long you hold the attack button. Also some characters have spammable moves that are really cheap whch can get extremely annoying especially if you find someone plaing them online.  -The difficulty spike is awful, unlike ninja storm 2 where the opponents became more difficult over time, this one just has enemies towards the end spamming you with moves you can't dodge and just get overwhelmed with nothng to do about it, and throwing as many enemies as possible at you, either one at a time or all together, neither is fun.  -There is no free roam and most side quests are taken out, once again unlike ninja storm 2 there is no free roaming, the game tells you where to go and you can't do anything to stop it. The side quests have devolved to fetching items for one or two people where you can only get back to them once you complete the game, where you do get to free roam when you complete the game it's not as good due to the sour taste left in your memory having to fight through the main story's corridors.  -The lip synching is laughable, there is no attempt to match the character animation with the english version script. I know it's difficult but it looks like they made no effort with the characters lips still moving for a litle while even after their dialogue is finished (I would suggest to have it in japanese and put on english subtitles, the voice actors are much beter and it looks like the characters are actually talking).  All in all the game isn't bad, but it's nothing special, The story is great (apart from all of the cutscenes) but the combat is nothing out of this world, I would say that if you wanted a better naruto game go back to Ultimate Ninja Storm 2, it was much better done in basically every aspect.  I'm not going to give this game a rating cause that is usually just the person that is reviewing its thought, so I will just say if you enjoy Naruto and want to start Naruto Shippuden but don't feel like going through 350+ of episodes, this game sums it up pretty well.

I really wasn't expecting much from this game I only have it because a friend gave it to me and I felt obligated to play it, but I'm glad I did because the game is actually a lot of fun.  I don't like the anime, so I really don't think I have any kind of bias supporting it at all. This is probably why I am getting sick of the story mode right now since the cut-scenes can drag on for quite a while and I found myself skipping them a lot when I got the general jist of what the scene was about (sometimes even before that) and I would sometimes lose the context of a curtain fight.  But this IS a fighting game so the story isn't important what is important is the fighting system and I really like it. It's quite unique from other fighting games I've played and still manages to keep a kind of 'easy to learn, hard to master' element.   Most of the characters are pretty ballenced, except for the ones that have very fast acting far-ranged moves (like the exploding birds from what-his-face) that make fighting them with another character a real chore when it requires a lot more skill to beat someone who's just spamming the X button all day that is just as strong as special attacks, but doesn't use any energy for some reason.   I wish the game had a few more options though, it's basically a boring story mode, or fight other people online. With the amount of resorces the delveopers put into the story mode I feel like they could have toned it down a little to allow room for other features.  But I digress, the fighting system was enough fun for me to sink more then 10 hours into the game, I just feel like the game could have used at least one other feature instead of another 3 hours of cut-scenes for the story mode.

I've never ever seen a game more rapidly and severely fluxuate between being incredible and awful before this one.  Combat mechanics are well put together aside from the items which I refuse to use. Certain fights shift gears into excellently coreographed QTEs (take note every other game ever made, this is how you do QTEs).   The storyline hamfisted in between the combat almost felt tacked on and bored me to tears. I just browsed the internet half-interested in what they were saying on occasion. I can't openly advocate skipping the cutscenes though since you'll be completely lost. It just felt very slowly paced, especially if the target demographic should already know the storyline.   The horrendously tedious post-game content should be ignored EXCEPT for the side mission shards at the very end of the storyline, that is the content they added specific to this re-release.   The final fight(s) can be impossible-tier but if you can get past the first half you'll utterly crush the rest in a satisfying fit of cathartic, indignified vengance. Oh and of course on this one fight you need to use items, you can't.   It's not a bad game by any means, why am I the only person who bought it? Perhaps everyone else got the previous versions released on console.

It's Just fun.   I personally haven't even cared for naruto games since about what... Clash of ninja... But this... It feels like someone took Dragonball Z Threw it on the floor and then smashed it with a gutted One Peice grand adventure.  As far as battling goes, It's your run or the mill kaiblast spam enabled fighter where you can either sweat it out with actual skill or 200 Million volts amal virtually the whole game. It does feel less enabled to do that seeing as the moves are very easy to do and a flick of the stick an change to varying combos. So it is very VERY easy to look and enjoy the game visually without buggering about specific moves or getting traped into a bind or ai that refuses to stop spamming you into the dirt. It's just fun. And it's sad that is the easiest way I can describe this game.  Just like most of the dragonball z series games, the game will give you the story while you play, though Naruto feels exponentially more immersive as to give you the mood and air of the moment while also letting you play, something that most attention to detail games like mass effect or such manage to so while you're playing. (or I really need to play newer games because a lot of newer games are just doing things right.) Nonetheless, instead of the normal something is about to happen here is what it is and a small flashback as to why, like sonic games and such. This game gives more of an RPG like place in the game, letting you observe details and characters from the beginning, and actively letting you use them, accompanied with allies who may have also been present. Long story short... It is really a great experience to be had.  Experience wise. The potential and overall delivery of the game is probably the best part to me. The menus and interface, the overworld and different types of battles as well as a grand sum of characters does very well as a fan service as well as a new game. Mob battles feel very much akin to games like dynasty warriors but multiplied by classic beat em ups. Small chechpointed areas and a fun way to see how your characters would work against everyone who isn't really a hero. It's beautifully presented, plays very smooth, and shows what the games can really become at any time provided people either ask for it or beg for a mod. It's hard to explain, But when you see two main characters and two assist characters on stage, it seems to really put up for some actual team battles. (Don't know if they exist)   All in all, It's surely a good time and plays as good as it looks creative. Shoot me in the foot though, as I wish whoever is pushing the art for borderlands would flip a few tables over here, because I'm almost too sure that the series could look like a tearfully joyous creation provided their models went through some other sort of process... You know... where bloom isn't a thing? But I know that that will probably never happen and if it did... I'd need to get some depends. No points against it at all for that, or anything for that matter.  I reccomend it for anyone who likes naruto or fighting games, open movement 3d fighting games to be specific, who also wanted to have rpg elements and unlockables along with scattered goodies that seperate it from normal fighting games.
This game is frikin sick!!! But... it has some lag spikes, just so you know... IMO, wait til it's 75% off, $29.99 is pretty xpensive ;)

Do you like visual novels pretending to be a fighting game? Do you like 30fps and a combat system that is half dynamic action button presses? Do you like watching the loading icon more than playing the actual game? Do you really really really like Naruto  If yes to any of these then this game is for you. I had never played any of the other games in the series but I figured It would be somewhat like mortal kombat, where the characters change as the story progresses. If only it had been more like mortal kombat. If you can manage to bear through the first hour or so of the game it starts to pick up...but what the hell is with the load times, sometimes it feels like the game is mocking you for wanting to, you know, actually play. here is a breakdown of how the game plays. loading screen/cutscene/loding/cutscene/loading/cutscene(yes you can skip them for the most part, however most dont have a dialog skip option so you have to wait for everyone to finish talking)/loading/pre battle planning/FIGHT/loading cutscene/cutscene/loading/walk naruto from one side of the path to the other/loading/loading loading.......I mean come on. Its more of an acion rpg/visual novel than a fighter. which is fine but when you have to load 3 seperate cutscenes before a fight it gets stupid, add on to that you have to load a (free world type) area where you just walk from one side of the screen to the other then it goes back to loading you might as well be putting in seperate disks for each fight, It feels like FFVII level of loading situations.  TLDR: loading screen/10

After playing this game for four hours--unable to stop myself until after I've progressed to Chapter 3, I can safely say that I REALLY enjoy this game. And that's coming from someone who does NOT like playing Fighting Games, I have a temper problem with getting hammered into the ground constantly and I have slammed my controller onto my table in a fit of rage once whilst playing this game but I can safely that was that due to the computer being a cheap ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and not so much my skill being obsolete! =P  The combat is VERY fluid and feels nice, the enemy will always adapt to the way you play.. if you beat on their face a lot they're going to teleport away a lot, if you hang at a distance and pelt them with ranged weapons they burst their way towards you to beat your face in. If you hammer them constantly with jutsu, they'll start blocking and dodging at the last second. Sometimes you have to alter your strategy on the fly and find ways to counter them, I've lost more than a few fights already and it's never a pleasant feeling when you 'DGAF' button gets pressed.  Story is pretty solid and makes you feel as if you're actually PLAYING the anime, not the game and draws you in. The pacing is perfect, the controls feel marvelous on my controller and it's not overly complicated like most fighting games tend to be. There IS no Right, down, circle down to right, b then wait 2 seconds then hit Y. It's just charge up, tap this button, now wait and avoid attacks and hit this button and BLAMMO, combo initiated. For that reason alone, I love the combat system. It's something that even a casual gamer like myself can enjoy. The difficulty of the story is unable to be altered, and the enemies scale in difficulty based on who you're fighting and how serious they're taking you, and if you lose to them too many times the game lowers their difficulty so you CAN beat them and progress so there's no wall blocking your progress.  You get rewarded for completing bonus objectives which are a lot of fun to do, especially when you finally land that specific requirement and can actually see what your new reward is! I tend to average either A's or S' for my ranks after defeating somebody, and it's very gratifying to see that high rank consisently. I honestly can find NOTHING wrong with this game, personally, and for that reason alone I'm giving this game a 10 out of 10. A must-have for ANY Naruto fan... though if you've never seen the end of the Series leading UP to Shippuden? You're probably going to be confused about a lot of things.

Naruto Ultimate Ninja Storm 3, in my humble opinion, is a really fun game with a few flaws keeping it from greatness. As an avid fan of the series both manga and anime, I decided to pick this game up after doing some research on it, and have been very pleased.   Disclaimer: This is my first ever Gamefaqs review; you have been warned  Graphics: 9/10  I think that the game is just beautiful! The character models are all rendered and match their anime counterparts nicely. While the graphics don't look exactly like the anime, I think thats a good thing. because it looks like a video game instead.  As you fight through the story, you will face a wide variety of characters, fight huge bosses, and you will get to visit a multitude of iconic locations from the series. Not one time in my playthrough did I say 'well that doesn't look very good.' The color, scenery, and vividness of the game really do an excellent job of capturing the Naruto Universe that we all know and love. Even the opening menus have a great amount of detail put into them.  Another big part of this game is the large, large, LARGE amount of cutscenes and action sequences, and I believe that they all look fantastic! There are massive explosions, high paced action, and gripping story moments that are all captured very well within the games engine.   However, there is at least one major fault, and its mainly because the game can get a little big for its britches sometimes. I don't think I experienced this at all throughout the story, but when playing in tournaments or online, if multiple jutsus and teammates start getting called, the game does have framerate issues. This is the sole reason this portion doesn't get a 10 from me.  Story: 8/10  Now, if we are just talking Naruto as the manga, I would personally give this a 10; but we're not, we are talking about Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 the game, and it does have some setbacks.  The game follows the story immediatley after Naruto's confrontation with Pain, and continues up almost to where the manga is currently. The main form of story progression is through cutscenes, which there are a ton of! Not that that is bad though. One cutscene in particular lasts at least 30 minutes, but it does a wonderful job of getting you immmersed in the story and if you are invested in the series (like me) you may even find yoursef shedding a tear or two! How many times can you say a video game has done that to you before?  My biggest qualm with the story has to do with the so called 'Ultimate Decisions' you make throughout the game, as they really don't do anything to effect the way that the plot unfolds. I think that in theory it was a good idea, but basically all it does is ramp up the difficulty (slightly) on certain missions. UNS3 is not a difficult game to begin with, and I would have rather seen two different endings than come to the same road at the end for some additional replay value.  The story also expects you to already know what is going on, so if you are on the fence about getting this and don't know your Naruto lore study it up or you will not have a clue about what's going on.  Sound: 8/10  Not much to say here. I thought that the music fit the mood for the game very nicely. Sad moments had soft piano keys playing in the background, and intense moments revved it up the way you would expect a Naruto game to. Everything in between was pleasant to listen to, it's just... it wasn't the original soundtrack. As much attention to detail as was put into everything else, I really wish they had gone ahead and gotten it, because you just can't replace it. I guess there were some copyright issues preventing its use.  Gameplay: 8/10  A cast of over 80 characters unite for some seriously over the top action that you can take on in the story mode, locally with friends, or online against the rest of the world! This game is so much fun to play! So why does it get an eight instead of 10, I will explain.   One downside is the very limited free roam that is offered. I almost thought why even include it, but it does open up from otherwise linear paths after you have completed the story. Basically sometimes you will watch a cutscene, then get sent to free roam. After running a short ways you will then enter another cutscene or battle. There is really not much to it other than that. You can talk to NPC's and there are a few sidequest offered, but they really didn't seem worth it to me unless you are going for all of the trophies. It is mainly just a means to an end to get you to the next battle. And that is where the meat of the game is anyway, the battles.  The game has both single and team battles. Single being just you as your character of choice (or who is currently the story character), while team battle allows you to pick one or two support characters to help you. The combat is fast paced, but never too difficult to follow, with exceptions being online sometimes.   You primarily attack with the circle button, or B button if you are on Xbox, and have three varying combos you can perform by just pressing circle and using the analog stick. Triangle is your chakra load button, X is jump, and square is the shuriken button. You have basic, and chakra loaded moves that you can execute by pressing the chakra button followed by a different command. This is how you execute your jutsu and ultimate jutsu attacks. You can also block by holding R2, though it can be broken, and you can use a substitution jutsu by pressing L2 while being attacked.  There are a variety of cancels that you can perform when executing attacks that will allow you to create your own, flashier combos, and add some depth to the gameplay. The most common of these is the Chakra Dash Cancel (CDC). Basically, while comboing or doing another action, you can press triangle and then X immediatly after to cancel whatever you were currently doing. These cancels are what really add the tactical aspects to battles, as well as providing ways to score big damage if you know what your doing.  All that being said, you will have a blast playing through the story mode, but you may experience frustration if you try to take the game online.  For me, it has mainly been connection issues. Lag is very, very abusable in this game. I cannot tell you how many times I have eaten a jutsu because the game read one extra circle press. Basically, when you are fighting someone online you need to conserve your chakra and your substitution jutsus more than anything. Play well, make the other guy run out of substitutes, and then punish them with big damage, thats how its supposed to go. However, get into a room with a little bit of input lag, and your read on when your opponent is going to substitue turns into a Rasengan Barrage because instead of being able to block or chakra cancel, the game said you hit attack again. It is playable though, and playing in rooms with little lag is a lot of fun. Winning against a good opponent is a very rewarding experience, not to mention you get to do all with your favorite Naruto characters! Both ranked and player matches are offered, as well as a tournament mode that I haven't gotten to try yet, but has a variety of different rules.  I would also have liked for this game to have been made with a more competitive aspect to it rather than almost strictly fanservice and casual. There is a skill aspect to it, some players are simply going to be better than you should you pick up the game, but there are some mechanics, like awakenings, that I do not like.   Awakenings are very powerful 'super modes' that characters can enter. Don't get me wrong, they look AWESOME and make you feel like a boss when you use them, but they need to go IMO. You could be playing the match of your life, and have your opponent down to half a bar left, but if they manage to get their awakening off they could easily turn the tide back in their favor, and I do not like mechanics that reward players for getting beaten. Instant awakening

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME IF YOU DO NOT OWN A CONTROLLER OR YOU ARE OK WITH USING A KEYBOARD.  I originally purchased this game on the PS3, and have many hours played on it. I recently purchased this game during the Steam Summer Sale, so regardless of my current time played on this game through Steam, I have alot of experience with this game outside of the PC version.  If you are a fan of the Naruto anime series, you will love this game. With that being said, the PC port for this game isn't what it should be. A controller heaps alot and the keyboard controls have to be manually set by the player in order to be used. Using a keyboard is highly discouraged with this game.  The game takes place just after the Pain Invasion Arc, and focuses on the Fourth Great Ninja War. The player takes the role of a few of the main characters as it follows each one through their perspective during the war. The story mode is a mix between long cutscenes, fights and free roam. The audio can be changed between English and Japanese (all with subtitles).  The cutscenes may be long but are necessary to develop the story. They can be skipped if wanted.   The fights are very fun and challenging, requiring certain techniques and strategies to be used to defeat the enemy. The fights can be considered 'button mashing', but skillfully uses certain attacks at certain points during the battle is a much better strategy than spamming the attack button.  The free roam can be very annoying and boring. Running from one village to another can take quite some time, and the side missions can sometimes be very boring.  The online battle mode could have been excellent if executed properly. It highly favours the host of the match, and adds artificial input lag to 'help' balance the connection disadvantages, but fails miserably. It is also very difficult to find anyone to play with within my region that has a decent connection. I'm sure with good connection, the online mode could be very fun.  The regular battle mode is very fun and can be customised to the players liking. It also features a tournament mode for those who want a fun and exciting challenge.  Overall, this is a very good game, but the PC port fails to live up to the hype. If you have a controller to use on your PC, this game is a must buy.

I should perhaps start off this review by stating that, while I am a fan of anime in general, I'm not really that into Naruto. The obvious question then is why did I play it, the answer to which is that I figured it would be like other game adaptations of bad source material that turn out good. Which, in some aspects, this is.  The main part of the game, which is of course the combat, is pretty good. I don't think I've actually played a 3D fighting game before this, but it's pretty accessible. The combos are simple enough to remember (and are optional to the overall experience anyway), the controls aren't deliberately broken so you have to buy a separate controller (I swear a lot of fighting and racing games actually do this), etc. and the characters seem balanced enough from what I can tell (I didn't really try the multiplayer stuff so who knows).  The visuals also manage to pull off the cel-shaded effect quite well and have a nice overall cinematic feel, and the soundtrack is fantastic. Voice acting is okay as well, with perhaps the exception of the main character. Seems to have the same actors as the anime series so fans of the actual series (whoever they are) might like that.  But with all this great stuff I'm saying about this game so far, you may wonder why there is a red thumb down at the top of this post. And it really boils down to the overworld parts in single-player when you aren't fighting, plus the save system.  It has a sort of open-world-but-not-really JRPG sort of feel with it. That's not the bad part, it's not a bad idea if it pulled it off that well. There are a few main problems I have with the execution here. Firstly, the damage you take in one fight remains in the overworld, and carries over to the next fight. This means that you will probably lose the next fight, and be given an option to either retry the battle with that same amount of health or to restore your health. You will be penalized for choosing the latter. Even when, and this is the second thing, there are like 5 battles in a row without a chance to go to any noodle shops or buy some healing items or anything at all. Normally this wouldn't be a problem, but combined with the first point, and the third point that I'm about to mention, it is simply painful.  The third point is the save system. Despite being a game released in 2013 (i.e. not in the 1980s, where perhaps technical limitations were an excuse for bad design) it still has save points. That doesn't make the game fun. I really don't know why some developers are incapable of understanding this. Most games with save points at least give you the option to do a quicksave which exits the game and gets deleted when you launch it again, but this doesn't even give you that. Just a couple of bird houses that you hardly get a chance to go to because it's just fighting non-stop, and at the end of each chapter.  This does not combine well with the fact that the first chapter at least (I don't know about later ones because I stopped playing when I finally finished it) is about an hour long. That's not even including cutscenes. As I said, I'm not a fan of the anime series, but I figured I'll watch the cutscenes anyway to give it a chance and to try and make sense of the plot (I think you have to play the first Naruto games first). Said cutscenes are around... 11 minutes long. I think they're skippable, but when you've finally got through 5 full fights and you wanted to stop playing 40 minutes ago but the game's lack of saving won't let you, an achievement pops up that says you apparently completed the chapter finally any cutscene that comes up with a 'better not skip this because it sounds important' vibe to it just feels like a slap in the face. Please stop, game.  I just want to go home. I feel kind of rude saying this, but I actually have other things to do than play this game non-stop. I really wonder how this part got past playtesting (if there was any). Did they not take into account that people actually have jobs, or kids, or whatever?  It's a shame really, because I wanted to like this game, and through the prologue and beginning of the first chapter I thought I was going to (minus the plot which I expected to not be great anyway, I'm not going to complain here about how this Sasuke guy is edgier than Shadow the Hedgehog made out of razor blades because it would be ignorant of the 'Naruto' in the title).

Amazing game. Solid single player with again more upgrades compared to the older versions, and ofcourse pc quality graphics.  The online seems to work smoothly ofcourse connecting to people who have a slow ISP will need more time to pick a character and load a map.  As for combat itself, theres 4 keys. Melee / Ranged / Chakra / Dash. But its not as simple as that. chakra+melee = special / chakra chakra melee = ultimate and so on, you can combine chakra activations with attacks and movement.  Also you can combine movements with attacks like holding down while tapping melee will result in a diffrent combo this will make your oponents timing on defending harder. If you like anime, Naruto, button masher and cel shader, grab this one!  Campaign is a very nice story adaption and not too hard. Playing it through unlocks all characters, too (takes less than 30h if you watch all scenes and hunt for rank S). But for unlocking, MP will work, too, as every fight rewards you with some money and unlocking works by gaining total amount X for each character and outfit.  Multiplayer works good: local 2 player, turnament mode for up to 8 player, online battles and is relativerly good balanced so far.  Fighting style is the most important, at least for me: You don't have to remember tons of combos like in Tekken or Mortal combat; there are some general combos working for every character and if you have your favourite, there are 3-4 more for each character; but you don't loose just because you don't know them by heart. Most of the time you 'just' have to react fast and correct instead of hammering 10-varying-button-combos. That makes it also a nice alternative for party games like Smash Brothers since it's relatively easy to learn, only mastering takes some time.

Being a fan of the 'Clash of Ninja' series I was really excited to play this Ninja storm series mainly because its on computer. Although this game has the best story i've seen in a 'fighting' game and its also very well polished I do find myself dissapointed in the combat mechanics.  You only have 1 ninjutsu and 1 ultimate ninjutsu per charecter. Along with a simple combo system I tend to get bored of each charecter quickly. Instead of quailty ninja with a variety of abilites they made a lot of the same ninja but with alternate 2 ninjutsu's for a overall higher number of ninja on the box. Theres about 4 or 5 different Naruto's and Sauske's to choose from all being about the same just 1 or 2 different abilities and costume.   Also theres no 2v2 or survival mode. Huge dissapointment if you have friends over. Your only option is to fight against your friend you can never fight WITH them like in Clash of Ninja.   The main reasons this game is better then Clash is for its Story mode and how it runs perfect on my computer. The Wii can't run a Naruto game without slowing down from the graphics, maybe the Wii-U could do it.   I'm going to finish this game mainly for the story but i've yet to find a ninja I like to play more then one battle at a time =\

Fighting as Kurama vs all other Bijous - absolute win! Bought an XBox PC gamepad for this, installed it, after a prologue battle with Minato against Tobi i was shocked. Was it really possible to create such an amazing anime fighting game? As a Naruto manga/anime freak since day one I was trying to be objective, but I was blown away. Simple controls, cool combos, amazing animations, catchy soundtrack, excellent japanese voice and other audio - 100% immersive and true to the Naruto setting. You can play as 80+ characters! C'mon, that alone was reason enough for me to buy the game - finally trying out what it's like to play as Mifune, Danzo and all the other kages and jinchurikis:) blown away once again. You will have many many hours to play if you are like me and wanna try out every character, every combo, every mission, challenge and full story. I also forgot to mention that cutscenes are like watching an anime show:) My only downside was lack of little-ping online battles and slow loading when doing 100% challenge missions, but other than that I give it a total 10/10. Funny, amazing, a must have for a Naruto fan - for all you others interested in a good fighting game don't worry - the game will pluck you in the Naruto world like a you've been struck by Kage Bunshin Rasengan:) now gtg, Naruto season 1 rewatching:)

I gave this game a bad review when i first played it my first time and... it still deserves a bad review. It may be good for console but not at all for PC. The controls you have to set up all manually, they are based off of an Xbox controller so if you are not familiar with it you are screwed in the story mode. Dont even get me started on online battles. theres hardly no connection literally every 3 seconds or less it freezes the game and says something along the lines of 'connecting' or something. the community is nothing but people who run away if you get close and spam you with ranged attacks so you cant do anything. i just feel there was literally no concideration for PC gamers at all when they put this game on steam and just used it as a way to grab more cash. Dont even get me started on the story mode. i got this game expecting.. well.. to play a game! The story mode is pretty much an almost never ending cutscene. i found myself skipping every cut scene just to get to a battle and even then you might have to skip probably up to 6 just to fight one battle. I have played the old narutos on my gamecube back in the day and they did an amazing job with the story modes but they have really ruined it now.
